title: Rosemary Goring  We need to change the way we work for women to succeed
story: Peachy as this may sound, all is not as equitable on the wards, in GP surgeries, and especially in operating theatres, as you might expect. An assiduous promoter of gender equality, Professor Belch pointed out that despite the wealth of opportunities open to women in medicine, when it comes to the most prestigious areas, such as heart surgery, men are still top dog.ldquoThese are jobs where you may be required to work from six in the morning to  at night, she said, ldquoand most women decided that they prefer to work part-time rather than commit to that. Not that she blames them: ldquoAfter all, we fought for their right to choose.Part-time employment is now the main obstacle in the campaign for women to be on a par with men. When a female doctor first hooks a stethoscope around her neck the future looks,not precisely plain sailing, then navigable.However,at some point she starts a family, or has older relatives to care for, opting to work part-time creates an unsolvable quandary. You could call the shorter working week a womanrsquos wrecking ball, the destroyer of youthful aspirations.Speak to thirtysomething medics, who started out intending to become heroic surgeons and physicians, and you will detect a weariness, and also a resignation to the fact that the conditions in which they are expected to perform are incompatible with any kind of normal le, let alone raising a family.As a result, an essential tier of the health system voluntarily removes itself from the full-time rota. And while hospital-based medicine is undoubtedly at the extreme end of professional expectations, given the prolonged, intense and erratic shts, what goes for medicine is also true of other careers: the advocate who must work into the small hours and over weekends to keep on top of her case load the head teacher who is in the school before breakfast, and once back home works until bedtime the farmer who labours every day of the year the journalist who cannot clock off until the late-breaking story is filed.No wonder people in these occupations wondertheyrsquove been put on the rack, as they are slowly stretched to breaking point. Yet when doctors, and other high-fliers, decide to go part-time, it is a self-inflicted slow puncture. All the training, expertise and experience they have acquired, all the momentum they have gathered, begins to deflate. Friends and family feel secretly disappointed that a seemingly stellar career has lost its stardust. Worse, the part-timer often feels she is in some unfathomable way to blame for not being able to juggle everybodyrsquos expectations, including her own, yet still have a le worth living.By drawing attention to the part-time glass ceiling, Professor Belch highlights how complicated and protracted the business of reaching true equality remains. The effort to increase the number of women entering medical school, which was once seen as the solution to the predominance of males, succeeded years ago. Indeed, that hurdle has been so successfully overcome there are sometimes more girls in class than boys.The problem is that, in the early years of feminism, none of us looked far enough ahead. Lacking imagination, perhaps, or brimming with optimism, we did not give a thought to the lelong path ndash more accurately a tight-rope ndash on which working women must keep their balance. Once aloft, they need to stay upright not merely when they are young and full of energy, but as their lestyles change, their commitments grow, and their attitudes mature.Belchrsquos comments are a long overdue corrective to the notion that the ward ndash or boardroom, laboratory, lecture hall ndash is as welcoming for women as men. In so doing she has also pointed to the unrealistically tough regime in which many professionals are expected to survive. Itrsquos not just women who have a family to raise, or other caring responsibilities, and itrsquos not just women who feel they must clone themselves in order to get through everything the working day ndash and the action-packed weekend ndash demands. Singletons, or those with partners but no children, can still find employersrsquo expectations excessive and debilitating. The dedication and single-eyed focus required to keep on top of the most responsible roles takes a toll on everyone.Doubtless burn-out existed in Edwardian times, it just didnrsquot have a label. Today we have inherited a pitiless culture in which status is calculated by how visibly gruelling your job is. The more punishing your hours and the less time you have at home, the higher your place on the ladder of awe. The employee who can be home shortly after five, and has all evening in which to help their kids with homework or go to the gym, is unlikely to score impressively on the Richter scale of professional achievement. Yet she, or he, might have a really well thought-out le, with their priorities in the right order.The dilemma facing society is not simply how to help part-time women reach the very top but how to recalibrate these Alpha workplaces. The challenge for employers who do not want talented staff to drt off or grow disheartened is to come up with ways to make these all-consuming roles desirable, but also manageable, for a far wider range of iniduals.At the moment, physical and psychological stamina are almost as essential as professional excellence for someone to thrive in such an environment. Yet how many does that automatically exclude  Instead of a place that resembles the trenches, we need to restructure hospitals, banks, or the courts, so that they properly value ambitious and able part-timers. Far from discriminating against their promotion, they should encourage it. A good place to start might be to banish the adjective ldquopart-time, and its belittling connotations, once and for all.

title: wild-camping-bid-ban-tents-scotlands-beauty-spots
story: But now, wild campers could find themselves barred from pitching up at certain spots and forced to use designated campsites after concerns about a rise in litter and antisocial behaviour.The Scottish Parliament is being asked to consider new legislation which would enable councils to prevent wild camping in areas regarded as inappropriate or particularly sensitive areas after a surge in problems along the popular North Coast  route.It comes amid rising concern over the mess some wild campers leave behind, including toilet waste, broken bottles and litter, plus their environmental impact ndash from damage to fragile landscapes caused by tyre tracks to chemical spillages.In some cases, wild campers have been accused of chopping down trees to start campfires which in turn raises the risk of wildfires, parking their vehicles overnight on blind corners or in single-track road passing places, and scorching grass with camper van cleaning chemicals.:Outdoors: Five great botanical gardens to visitHuman faeces left by wild campers has been found in picturesque spots such as Balnakeil Beach near Durness and even in a church graveyard.Now a petition launched by Highland SNP councillor Kirsteen Currie suggests legislation is needed to allow councils to create ldquono wild camping zones in order to protect the environment and infrastructure.She said the problem rests with a particular group of travellers who fail to respect the places they visit and can be aggressive when challenged.She said: ldquoPeople causing problems by roadside camping in really inappropriate, selfish places are not your lsquoput on gaiters and go for a nice walk Munro-baggersrsquo. Theyrsquore not hillwalking and outside types.ldquoThey are people who donrsquot want to spend pound or pound to use a campsite. And when someone challenges them ndash such as someone I know who asked a family to pick up dirty nappies they had left behind on a beach ndash they are met with aggression.ldquoAnd it doesnrsquot matter how many Countryside Code leaflets you print out, they are not reading them. I donrsquot want to impinge on anyonersquos rights to roam, I want to stop people having the right to make a mess.The petition says the impact of wild camping, particularly on the NC route, has been ldquoconsiderable and adds it has become ldquoexceptionally problematic for local authorities and public bodies to deal with and at great expense to the public purse.:Herald Entrepreneur: Hone your vision so you have a strong foundation from which to build your businessIt points out that the problem isnrsquot restricted to the areas which line the NC route, with complaints about the impact of wild campers emerging from the Western Isles and other Scottish tourist hotspots across the country.In it, Currie adds: ldquoInformal encouragement has not been sufficient to stop the degradation of our infrastructure and environment.ldquoEven with an increased focus on responsible camping from public authorities and the NC organisation, the situation appears to be getting worse rather than better.ldquoThe route of the NC is becoming totally unsuitable for small rural communities in the north of Scotland.The NC tourist trail has been credited with transforming tourism to Scotlandrsquos northwest coast since its launch in .Most travellers opt to start at Inverness and take in a -mile loop around the northern tip of the mainland, before eventually ing to the Highland capital.Part of its charm is the long distances travellers can cover without encountering the distractions of modern le, around one-fth of it on narrow, single-track roads.With accommodation limited to small BBs, inns and hotels, many visitors opt to travel the route in campervans or with tents for camping under the stars.But while the route is said to have added at least pound million to the regionrsquos economy and brought over , visitors, people living in the area have become increasingly outspoken over the impact of tourism on their fragile environment.Wild camping is legal in Scotland. However, campers are expected to stick to the Scottish Outdoor Access Code which suggests it should involve camping for just two or three nights at a time and be ldquolightweight, with small numbers of people and no trace left on the natural surroundings.According to the Holyrood petition, no camping zones would allow local authorities to encourage responsible tourism and encourage campers to use campsites and their facilities to dispose of waste properly.It could see camping banned at increasingly popular wild camping sites near cities in areas such as Ayrshire, West Dunbartonshire, Fe, East Lothian and Aberdeenshire.The petition does not set out to ban wild camping entirely, just from areas close to roadsides which are becoming overwhelmed with campers.Wild camping has already been outlawed around parts of Loch Lomond.But there are concerns about how stringently councils will impose the no camping rules which could affect mountaineers and walkers who want to pitch a tent during overnight expeditions.Responses to the online petition have included comments which support the call and highlight inidual problem areas. One claims that campervans park within  metres of a campsite in Tongue rather than use its facilities, while another said simply: ldquoDone seeing bins overflowing in the middle of nowhere and people having a lsquonumber tworsquo outside their camping site.Another wrote: ldquoHaving visited the south side of Loch Tummel for nearly  years it has been devastating to witness the rubbish people leave behind when wild camping.ldquoSome of my favourite walking spots are now no-go areas due to human waste and view spots are ruined by rubbish.Others, however, spoke out against the idea of legislation with one commenting: ldquoEroding the rights of all citizens is not the answer.Another said: ldquoImposing complete bans totally ruins it for those acting responsibly and goes against everything the current outdoor access code stands for.Helen Todd, Ramblers Scotlandrsquos campaigns and policy manager, said: ldquoSadly there are ongoing issues in hotspot areas with an antisocial minority who are damaging the environment, the reputation of campers and the outdoor experience for everyone who loves our countryside.ldquoThe entire outdoor community shares the frustration of residents about these people, whose selfish actions impact upon communities, landscapes and the thousands of responsible people who enjoy camping away from formal sites across Scotland.ldquoWe are calling for antisocial camping to be tackled through stronger enforcement of the existing laws, provision of facilities and more low-cost campsites, and investment in education on responsible access ndash rather than new costly and ineffective laws or by-laws, which themselves would need enforced.ldquoIn many instances, responsible roadside camping away from houses is legal, legitimate and simply the best option.ldquoFor example, winter climbers arriving late ahead of a pre-dawn start, cycle tourers, disabled campers who benefit from being near their car, canoeists and anglers at road-circled lochs and long-distance walkers.She added: ldquoRather than banning campers, the best solution is to try out ious visitor management measures, such as investment in infrastructure like low-cost campsites, toilets and litter bins, and lots of education. This should be monitored and adjusted as time goes on to find out what works best.ldquoIn addition, enforcement of existing legislation like breach of the peace, vandalism and littering can be carried out by the police in areas known to be hotspots.ldquoI donrsquot think anyone involved with setting up NC expected it to be as spectacular a success story in terms of numbers, but the infrastructure is not there. They put the cart before the horse. A lot of public money was spent marketing this route but there was a failure to provide an effective infrastructure for anyone using it.A spokesman for North Coast  said: ldquoLitter is a problem associated with most human activities and it should be recognised that residents are as likely to be responsible as visitors for negligent waste disposal. We encourage all visitors to the North Coast  to travel with respect for the environment. We share top tips on our website and social media channels in order to reach as many people as possible, including visitors and locals.ldquoThis information includes content on anti-litter campaigns, details of campsites around the NC route, and advice on how visitors should dispose of their motorhome waste in the correct manner. We work with organisations such as Keep Scotland Beautul to educate and encourage responsible and sustainable litter disposal along the route.

title: support-scottish-independence-rises-50-according-new-poll
story: The Panelbase survey for The Sunday Times Scotland also found more respondents than not believe the Scottish economy would be better off with independence in the EU than in the UK after Brexit.The % figure backing independence marks a five point increase on the % Panelbase registered on average in its polls last year, which mirrored the % yes % no result of the  independence referendum.It is up on the % recorded in the papers last poll in June and is a record high for its regular Panelbase polls on the issue.:Ian Blackford says Scottish independence vote has to happen next yearGiven a choice between a no-deal Brexit and an independent Scotland, there was a - lead for independence, up two points since April.The poll of , voters in Scotland carried out between Wednesday and Friday found % of people believe Scotland will be better off economically as an independent country within the EU rather than staying in the UK after Brexit.Just over a thirddisagreed while one in fivesaid they did not know.The findings were released on the morning of the SNPs autumn conference in Aberdeen, where the partys Westminster leader is expected to tell delegates Scottish independence will be the focus of any forthcoming general election campaign.He will say that retaining the partys majority of Scottish seats at Westminster will re-affirm the mandate to hold another referendum on Scottish independence.The poll indicates large gains for the SNP at the next general election, with the party on %, up one percentage point since June.The Conservatives are also predicted to gain at %, up three percentage points since June, while Labour are on %, up two.The Liberal Democrats are unchanged on % and the Greens unchanged on %, while the Brexit Party was on %, down four percentage points since June.:Scottish Greens launch  election campaignSir John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde University, told the paper the Conservatives face losing more than half of their Scottish seats.He calculates the SNP will win  seats - up from  at the  general election - with the Scottish Tories falling from  to five, Labour from seven to one, and the Lib Dems rising from four to five.The SNPrsquos Depute Leader Keith Brown welcomed the findings, saying:ldquoThis is a great way to kick off SNP conference in Aberdeen mdash with people across Scotland increasingly convinced of the case for Scotland becoming an independent country.ldquoWe have the mandate, we have a majority in the Scottish Parliament and wersquove got the momentum behind us.ldquoIf an independence referendum was held tomorrow it would be too close to call. And as we keep making that positive case for taking all decisions for ourselves as an independent country, support will continue to grow and grow.ldquoNow more than ever people realise the damage that is inflicted on Scotland by Westminster governments we donrsquot vote for. And people think our best future lies as an independent country at the heart of Europe, not part of an increasingly isolationist Britain.ldquoAnd people continue to put their trust in the SNP to deliver for them and their families at Holyrood, and to stand up for Scotland at Westminster.ldquoScotland will have the choice over our future, sooner rather than later, and I have no doubt that people will grab that opportunity to build a fairer, more prosperous country with independence.

title: sturgeon-refuses-rule-hard-border-england-independence
story: The First Minister told the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr show she did not want a border, but did not dismiss the idea of infrastructure and checksScotland was in the EU and England was outShe said: ldquoItrsquos not my choice. But we have to take these things step by step.She added she would be "frank and honest with people in Scotland about the choices Irsquom asking them to make".The opposition said the SNPs "mask has slipped" after years of the party refusing to acknowledge a hard border could be a result of dferent trading regimes in Scotland and England.Ms Sturgeon was asked whether a hard border was avoidablethe UK underwent Brexit and erged from EU rules and taxes, then Scotland went back in.In that situation, the Scottish-English border would also be an EU external border, and so potentially subject to customs and regulatory checks.Ms Sturgeon said English ergence from the EU regime after Brexit was ldquoa real danger and why she did not want Scotland to be ldquotrapped but to chart its own course.She said: ldquoI donrsquot underestimate the dangers and the damage of a Boris Johnson-led government in a race to the bottom prioritising trade deals with the likes of Donald Trump.Pressed on a potential hard border, she said: ldquoI donrsquot want borders. Itrsquos not my choice. But again, we have to take these things step by step.ldquoI am not the author of the Brexit policy. I am opposed to the Brexit policy. Itrsquos not my choice to have policies that result in borders. I donrsquot want Scotland and I donrsquot see why Scotland does have to choose.When it was put to her she might nevertheless have to deal with a border being ldquofoisted on her, she said: ldquoI will. But what Irsquom not going to do is to speculate and answer questions on the basis of detail that we donrsquot yet have, and a scenario that we donrsquot yet know the nature of.ldquoSo I will always be frank and honest with people in Scotland about the choices Irsquom asking them to make.ldquoOne of the things I am determined about is that the choice that Scotland will make on independence, just as it was in , will be an informed and a detailed one. We wonrsquot plaster lies on the back of a bus and cross our fingers and hope we get away with it.Press again on whether a hard border was inevitableScotland was in the EU and England wasnrsquot, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThat question had a number of s in it, and thatrsquos the point I am making. We need to see how things play out and what the final relationship between the UK and the EU will be.ldquoI am not of the view that what yoursquove described, what Boris Johnson wants, is an inevitability, and I will continue to argue against that.ldquoBut as that picture claries I will be honest with the people of Scotland. But that opens a situation where Scotlandrsquos best interests depend on being independent and in charge of our own future, and I donrsquot want borders, it is not my policies putting borders anywhere.Asked how long she thought it would take Scotland to be admitted to the EU as an independent member state, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoNot very long. Irsquom not going to sit here and put a timescale on that because we would have to properly, responsibly, in a mature way, have these discussions.ldquoBut I speak to people in the European institutions and member states regularly as part of my job as First Minister. I think there is a real appetite to see Scotland in the EU.ldquoI think there would be open arms for Scotland. And I donrsquot think that would be a process that of necessity take a particularly long period of time.Acting Scottish Tory leader Jackson Carlaw said: ldquoNicola Sturgeonrsquos acceptance that Scottish independence will most likely lead to a border with England is a dramatic sht.ldquoUp until now the Nationalists have refused to accept this as even a possibility but they are can see they are fooling no one.ldquoSturgeon must now continue to be honestrsquo and admit that separation from the UK would lead to extreme austerity, hard borders with England and damage to public services.Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoThe mask has slipped. For Nicola Sturgeon any price is worth paying to break up the United Kingdom, even iding friends and family with a hard border.ldquoThe SNP should learn the lessons of Brexit, we need close ties with our neighbours not new barriers."Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard added: "We need to resolve the constitutional crisis - not create another one."Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said: ldquoNicola Sturgeonrsquos refusal to rule out a hard border with England has exposed the devastating reality of leaving the UK.ldquoCreating a barrier with the rest of the UK following Scexit would cause unimaginable damage for our economy, as well as separating us from our families and friends.ldquoSixty per cent of our trade is with the rest of the UK, demonstrating the importance of remaining in the UK for businesses and jobs.ldquoBut Nicola Sturgeon is prepared to take a wrecking ball to our economy, take away the pound, and erect a hard border with England.ldquoThe only way to avoid this catastrophic outcome is to remain in the UK.

title: issue-day-50p-turns-50
story: The p is  years old The seven-sided coin is celebrating its golden jubilee, but it had a challenging start as it was the third decimal coin to be introduced into the British currency ahead of decimalisation on February ,  - known as D-Day. The public were still grappling with the p and p and were yet to be introduced to the p, p and  p.It wasnrsquot popular Aside from the public having to adjust to the spate of new coins, many also felt that despite the prsquos distinctive shape - the only heptagonal coin in the world - the new arrival, made of cupronickel, was too easily muddled up with the p or half crown coins. The British press were not fans. One headline described it as a ldquomonstrous piece of metal.Why was it introduced in the first place By the late s, -shilling banknotes were being used so intensively they lasted only a few months. In comparison, the new coin would have a le-span of at least  years. It was struck bearing the decimal denomination of p but it circulated for the first couple of years as a -shilling piece. With the adoption of the decimal system, the value switched to  new pence.And the shape was by design - it was easier to roll smoothly in vending machines.There was a campaign against it Retired Army Colonel, Essex Moorcoft, formed the ldquoAnti-Heptagonists organisation, branding the new coin ldquougly and ldquoan insult to our sovereign whose image it bears.But the original coins endured The originals - featuring a portrait of Queen Elizabeth with a figure of Britannia on the reverse with a shield, olive branch and trident sitting alongside a lion - stayed in circulation until . They were then replaced with a re-sized smaller version.There have been lots of designs over the five decades Over the decades, the p has celebrated British achievements, events and milestones, with many commemorative ps introduced and limited editions changing hands for hundreds of pounds.In , a p featuring a design of clasped hands in a circle - to represent the nine members of the European Community - marked the th anniversary of the UK joining the EU. Also that year, a coin featuring a pair of hands against a pattern of radiating lines marked the th anniversary of the NHS.To mark the occasion Several special coins have been reissued, including a p marking Kew Gardenrsquos th anniversary. The Kew coin was introduced  years ago and remains a collectorrsquos item as only just , were made, making it the rarest p in circulation. Almost all of them are in private hands now and the chances of finding one in your change are slim.And p went a lot further  years ago Those were the days - it could buy you a round of drinks in the pub or even stretch to a trip to the cinema.

title: sturgeon-avoids-conference-split-referendum-policy
story: After she andWestminster leader Ian Blackford urged them to do so, delegates at the SNP conference overwhelmingly refused to debate a ldquoPlan B on independence.There were boos and jeers from leadership loyalists when the idea was advocated by Inverclyde councillor and National Executive member Chris McEleny.With the UK government refusing to grant Holyrood the power to hold Indyref, Mr McEleny and SNP MP Angus Brendan MacNeilhad proposed an alternative route.Their Plan B would see an SNP win in a general or Holyrood election taken to be a mandate to start immediate negotiations for independence.The plan flies in the face of Ms Sturgeonrsquos insistence that only a legal referendum based on the ldquogold standard of  would be regarded as internationally credible.:Sturgeon refuses to rule out hard border with England after independenceAfter twice failing to get the Plan B idea included in the conference agenda, Mr McEleny needed a two-thirds vote by delegates to have it discussed as ldquoadditional business.He said:ldquoI think that as a democratic political party itrsquos absolutely legitimate that we, the grassroots members of this party, have at least the opportunity to debate a Plan B at our party conference.ldquoPlan A is the plan that we want to have. We have a triple-lock mandate for an independence referendum. But we have a usurper Prime Minister in Boris Johnson who refuses to accept the democratic mandate of Scotland.ldquoThatrsquos why I support a Plan B and I think we should at the very least have a debate on."You may not agree judging by some of your boos in the front row - which I donrsquot think is within the proud traditions of this party"But we are a democratic political party and vibrant political debate is what has made this party what itrsquos been for  years."However activists at The Event Complex Aberdeen overwhelmingly rejected having a debate after Ms Sturgeon made her oppositioncrystal clear.In a series of Sunday newspaper articles, the SNP leader said those promoting a Plan B were falling into a Unionist trap by pushing an option that would not deliver independence.:Nicola Sturgeon accuses SNP rebels of helping UnionistsShe said: ldquoIf we were to try to hold a referendum that wasnrsquot recognised as legal and legitimate - or to claim a mandate for independence without having demonstrated majority support for it - it would not carry the legal, political and diplomatic weight that is needed.In his opening address to conference in Aberdeen, Mr Blackford echoed her warning.He told activists: ldquoWhen you hear talk of a so-called Plan B, I ask you to consider this.ldquoThe time to talk of a Plan B is not when Plan A has momentum.ldquoPlan Bs are by definition second best. Thatrsquos why our opponents would love us to sht onto that ground - it concedes their right to block the best route to independence.ldquoWhen it comes to choosing Scotlandrsquos future, we should demand and win the gold standard for democracy and for our country.:Defeat for SNP hopeful in dirty tricks rowA new poll for the pro-independence Wings over Scotland website has found four out of five Yes supporters wantsome form of Plan B.The most popular alternative, with % support, was legislating for a referendum without UK consent and then challenging the UK Government to challenge it in court.More than a third, %, backed the MacNeil-McEleny plan.After his call for a debate was rejected, Mr McEleny said: "I fully accept the decision of conference delegates, who were swayed with the high profile level of opposition."Time will tell whether or not we do need a Plan B, but the day an SNP representative decides not to progress an argument they believe in, just because theyrsquore scared it might not be popular, is the day we are worse of as a party."So Irsquom not down-beaten by the outcome and thank all the grassroots independence supporters for their kind words. ldquo

title: varied-roles-scots-women-last-century-documented-old-films
story: As the camera rolled, women played the bagpipes and rowed boats, taught, typed, tinkered with the car and quietly questioned why teachers bothered when it seemed all they wanted them to do was get married and run a home.Captured in hazy black and white and glorious technicolour, a collection of films which document the ied roles of women in Scotland through the last century are set toto the screen, providing a glimpse into their hopes, domestic and workplace drudgery and their refusal to conform.The rare footage has been brought together for a new touring programme dedicated to women on the screen which spans the Edwardian era to the Thatcher years.A joint project involving Film Hub Scotland and the National Library of Scotland, Her Century will tour the country with the intention of sparking debate about the lives of women in the past and reflecting on how the challenges they faced paved the way for women today.Among the films are educational and promotional material often commissioned by government to help steer women towards the right careers or to offer advice on health and behaviour.They are accompanied by amateur footage capturing women sharing a laugh or caring for family, and government propaganda and war-time film.The woman range from crofters to campaigners, schoolgirls to factory workers carrying out duties amid grime and fish workers, some little more than -years-old who have left their family home to work in stinking processing yards in the south of England.Dr Emily Munro, Her Century curator and Learning and Outreach Officer for the National Library of Scotland, said the collection of films, which were screened in their entirety at the Macrobert Centre in Stirling yesterday, reflect a time of rapid social change, when a "womanrsquos place" was increasingly contested and redefined.ldquoItrsquos as much about what wersquore missing from the films as what we can see in them, she said.ldquoWe can see from the films that some things have changed for the better, but that there are also some things we have lost, such as traditional industries which were often were women worked.ldquoI wanted something that is celebratory and positive about women, but also that raises questions for people.Among the earliest films to feature in the project is a  film Herring Harvest at Yarmouth, showing lsquoScotch lassiesrsquo at work some  miles from home.ldquoSome of the girls were just  or  years old, added Dr Munro, ldquobut would have left home and travelled all that way because that was where the work was.Other films focus on clippies and domestic science lessons, biscuit factory workers at Macfarlane Langrsquos Glasgow factory making Rich Tea and cream crackers and women making rles at a furniture makers workshop during the Second World War, and inspiring  silent footage of Winnie Drinkwater, a pilot and aviation pioneer.In contrast is a  Scottish Health Education Unit film, Male and Female, made by Jewish-Indian film-maker Sara Erulker and intended to be shown to teenagers as part of a series aimed at guiding them into adulthood.ldquoIt was meant to be open-ended and not prescriptive which is quite fascinating in itself, and addressed issues in teenagersrsquo lives such as sexual relationship, drunkenness, and gender expectations, said Dr Munro.ldquoMale and Female is a fascinating film some of the views the teenagersrsquo have are quite progressive and others are quite conservative.ldquoThe reflects the moment in time, where new freedoms and possibilities were emerging but also there was political conservatism.ldquoThe film was made in Glasgow and featured local teenagers, so it would be particularly interesting to find out what happened to them.While some of the films have been made by women, they rarely reflect strong feminist views. However, one film made by two women from Sheffield Film Co-operative in , Red Skirts on Clydeside, does examine of the most celebrated of womenrsquos battles - the Glasgow Rent Strikes of , told through the voices of the women descendants.ldquoItrsquos interesting that this film wasnrsquot made by women who lived in Scotland ndash or even men in Scotland, adds Dr Munro. ldquoItrsquos almost aswe were ambivalent about our own social political history as far as women were concerned.ldquoThe film poses important questions about why womenrsquos history is so hidden, and where can you go to hear about it.While some films show women taking on male roles during the Second World War, another highlights the impact of women lsquohaving it allrsquo and urges communities to come together to support vulnerable children left at home while women go to work.Dr Munro says taken together, the films spotlight the great iation in womenrsquos roles over the period, and draw on the iety of ways in which women and girls are represented on film, as scholars, workers, mothers and friends.The Her Century programme is being accompanied by a lsquozinersquo featuring women writers exploring the experiences, identities and perspectives of young women and girls.Sambrooke Scott, Film Hub Scotland Manager said: ldquoWersquore delighted that Her Century is screening across the breadth of the Film Hub Scotland network, from the Isle of Tiree to St Andrews, over the next six months until International Womenrsquos Day in March . Wersquore dedicated to bringing archive film to audiences across Scotland and collaborating with partners Her Century has the power to spark important discussions about equality that we can all contribute to.

title: looking-tranquility-plocktons-place
story: Plockton, is the harbour community in Wester Ross famed as the location for the fictional ldquobeat of s TV policeman Hamish Macbeth, starring Robert Carlyle and was the setting for parts of the  horror film The Wicker Man.Now the village, which benefits from the warming effects of the North Atlantic Drt, and is a magnet for holidaymakers with its array of brightly painted cottages has been ranked as the most tranquil getaway in the UK.:Highland Collective on a mission to photograph the glories of ScotlandThe village got the highest overall score of . out of , in an analysis gained from a shortlist of  UK destinations.Taking into account population size, remoteness, number of rentable cottages and how often they are referenced as lsquobeautulrsquo online, the villages and towns that were considered were said to be the ldquoperfect remedy for those wanting to get away from the hustle and bustle.Seven of the top , featured in the campaign were in Scotland, with Plockton the cream of the crop and described as ldquothe UKrsquos ultimate tranquil haven.The research, carried out by furniture design firm Arlo and Jacob, said of Plockton: ldquoVisited by tourists each year for its picturesque seaside setting surrounded by hills, this quaint location is home to a population of just  people, the second-lowest of all destinations analysed.The village, which was developed as a herring port in the early th century is now a haven for summer visitors including artists and yachtsmen.ldquoDespite its staggeringly low population, Plockton holds the th highest number of rentable cottages at  and is  miles away from the nearest major city, making it the ultimate tranquil getaway for those wanting a break from the busyness of everyday le, said the research.Timothy Newsome, marketing director from Arlo  Jacob said: ldquoItrsquos really important to take time for ourselves to relax and get away from our daily routines, no matter how hard it may seem. Travelling to a new destination is greatly beneficial and allows us to get a change of scenery and switch off from the responsibilities we usually face each day.:Wild camping: bid to ban tents in Scotlands beauty spotsldquoItrsquos great to see so many picturesque spots to choose from across the UK to get the retreat we are all in need of. From historic, picturesque English villages with Instagram-worthy rentable cottages to stay in, to stunning backdrops of mountains and valleys in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, all of these locations offer the perfect setting for escape, relaxation and pristine tranquillity.To establish the UKrsquos ultimate tranquil destinations the researchers collated a seed list of the most popular tranquil destinations mentioned in over  articles and blog posts.They then analysed these villages and towns also taking into account the number of miles from the nearest major city and the number of mentions in a collection of articles.Tobermory, the capital of the Isle of Mull, came fourth on the tranquil destination list and the research highlighted the ldquocolourful houses and quaint little bay and ldquogreat views across the port.Finishing th was the Fort Augustus, a village sitting south west of Loch Ness which is described as the ldquoultimate paradise for the keen walkers and cyclists wanting to escape for a weekend.Portree, the capital of the Isle of Skye finished th. It was described as a ldquostunning fishing village, surrounded by hills and filled with plenty of things to do for visitors. The study said it was an ldquoideal destination for those break looking for somewhere calmer and quieter ldquopositioned a staggering  miles from the nearest major city.Coming th on the list was Killin, the Stirlingshire which the judges said ldquooffers spectacular views as it sits along Loch Tay. They added: ldquoFamous for its salmon fishing and watersports, this location is the perfect outdoor getaway.Featuring ldquocobbled streets, jaw-dropping clfs and quaint fishing cottages, Crail, the small Fe harbour town took th spot.In th place was the village of Braemar in Royal Deeside which the survey said was ldquosurrounded by mountainous scenery, pine forests and an abundance of wildle. It said Braemar was ldquoa village for nature lovers and anybody that likes to go outdoors.Coming in as the UKrsquos second top tranquil destination - and Englandrsquos overall winner - is Castle Combe, Wiltshire, sitting in the famously beautul Cotswolds area and which is one of the UKrsquos top staycation destinations.

title: andrew-marr-show-ridge-sunday-reviews
story: this week found themselves instead on the Sunday show equivalent of a replacement bus service, going nowhere fast.Even though Peston has moved to midweek, leaving two Sunday television shows instead of three, the marketplace remains crowded, with radio, newspapers, and websites also vying for guests and news lines.: Sturgeon refuses to rule out hard borderRidge on Sunday, once again seeing the A-listers going to The Andrew Marr Show, was its usual inventive self. Much in the way Strictly Come Dancing has its movies week and its Blackpool week, Sky News promised ldquoleaderrsquos week, with Jeremy Corbyn on a pre-record from Hastings Jacob Rees-Mogg, leader of the Commons, live from what looked like his constituency home in SomersetLib Dem leader Jo Swinson in the studio and SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford at the partyrsquos conference in Aberdeen.The Rees-Mogg interview was hit by technical problems, requiring Ridge to talk over footage of PM Boris Johnson meeting his Irish counterpart Leo Varadkar, while someone tried to sort out the gremlins.As luck would have it, there was help at hand. Instead of asking Ridge to carry on winging it, the director cut to Jo Swinson in the studio. ldquoThanks very much for whizzing up into the gallery at short notice there, said Ridge.No mention was made of the East Dunbartonshire MP breaking any sprint records to go with Eliud Kipchogersquos historic marathon run of under two hours, but one imagines that, given the chance to upstage Rees Mogg, she went at a fair old lick. Think of the scene in Broadcast News where the production assistant races to get a tape on air, ducking open filing cabinet drawers and hurdling a toddler as she goes. Bit like that was it, Ms S Rees Mogg was back soon enough, laughing off the technical dficulties asto say, ldquoWhat  should one expect dealing with this new fangled electricity : Indy support rises to %When askedthe Government should not mind its language, such as labelling the Benn legislation the ldquoSurrender Act, the Minister said this was all part of the cut and thrust, and ldquothe socialists had done the same thing when dubbing the community charge the poll tax. It was not to be confused with the kind of unacceptable language and threats being sent on social media, particularly to ldquolady broadcasters. Is there a club for such ladies, andnot I wonder how fast Kay Burley can set it up Then again, looking at the line-up on Marr, perhaps such an institution is not needed to advance the cause of women on television. Too often on programmes with outside contributors the viewer is left asking the question, ldquoWhere are all the women  On Marr it was more like, ldquoWhat happened to the men The newspaper review  was all female, and the interviews were with Nicola Sturgeon, SNP leader and Scotlandrsquos First Minister, Priti Patel, Home Secretary, and Rebecca Long-Bailey, the Shadow Business Secretary. For the record, the sky did not fall in.Sunday Politics Scotland opted for strict equality in guests, featuring interviews with Kirsty Blackman, the SNPrsquos deputy leader at Westminster, and Lesley Laird, Shadow Scottish Secretary, and a male duo on the review of the week.: Split on policy avoidedBlackman had an uncomfortable time of it, appearing to be caught on the hop over whether the SNP,an amendment was tabled next Saturday on a referendum, would support it. After making several attempts at getting a yes or no, presenter Gordon Brewer said: ldquoThatrsquos all very interesting but itrsquos the answer to a dferent question from the one I asked you. So it went on, with Ms Blackman finally reduced to arguing that Brewer didnrsquot understand the ldquocollegiate way the SNP took decisions.In the paper review, Marr made much of the Scottish papers taking dferent lines from their equivalents in England, but he only showed a few front pages. No Sunday National, no Scotland on Sunday, The Herald on Sunday, Sunday Post, etc. Whoever went for the Scottish papers that morning had come back almost empty-handed.The subject of most speculation across all the shows was what would happen next Saturday, with Labour and the SNP almost negotiating over the airwaves as to what might be the price of any co-operation between the two. Nicola Sturgeon set down her red line: ldquoIf you donrsquot accept Scotlandrsquos right to choose our own future, at the time of our own choosing, donrsquot even bother picking up the phone to me.If you had ever wondered what the political equivalent of the phrase ldquotalk to the hand cos the face ainrsquot listening might sound like, Ms Sturgeon had just demonstrated. Donrsquot know about lady broadcasters, but the women on telly club had enjoyed a good day.

title: Marianne Taylor  Sturgeon is spot on   MPs should bin Boris and his dodgy deal
story: ldquoIf you donrsquot give us what we want wersquoll be very, very naughty! screamed the memo, which outlined the ways in which the UK would seek to punish EU states that agreed to give the UK an extension, should a deal not be reached by October . Putting such countries at the ldquoback of the queue for a trade deal and withdrawing defence and security co-operation were mooted, as was refusing to co-operate with and raty EU business. Elsewhere, there was talk of getting Hungaryrsquos populist right-wing leader to vote against the extension . How Angela and Emmanuel must have creased with laughter as they read all this tosh, not least because the threats show how little Cummings understands ndash or admits to understanding ndash about how the EU works."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Countdown to Brexit:  days until Britain leaves the EU","description": "Countdown to Brexit:  days until Britain leaves the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media ycZusvf poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests ycZusvf.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Brexit talks move to final phase after breakthroughNot that this was aimed at an EU audience, of course. No, Big Bad Domrsquos hysterical hardman nonsense was for the benefit of the home crowd, yet another attempt to attribute blame for the failing ldquoall or nothing approach that is being thwarted at every turn. Looks like Cummings could be running out of dead cats to hurl.The memo also highlights that despite all the trash talk, Johnson sees no way around the extension contained in the so-called Benn Act. Thatrsquos probably why the mood music became more upbeat during the latest round of talks with Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar trying to get a deal is simply Johnsonrsquos next roll of the dice. The prize he truly covets, of course, isa majority in parliament whether that happens off the back of a deal or no-deal is a mere moot point to this reckless PM.Despite a move to substantive negotiations, there is still no guarantee that a deal can or will be struck with the EU. ButMr Johnson does manage to wrest an agreement that the EU and Ireland can live with ndash one which will, in yet another surreal and eye-rolling twist to the Brexit debacle, basically be Theresa Mayrsquos deal all over again ndash it creates a dilemma for the opposition parties.How should they respond to a potentially dangerous situation wherein the PM gleefully passes the buck to MPs, daring them not to raty his deal as the clock ominously ticks down, setting up the next play in his intellectually bankrupt but politically expedient blame game Yet again, Nicola Sturgeon has shown sense and leadership by making clear that her MPs will not vote for it. Why would they  Ms Sturgeon has been consistent from the outset: her party will not vote for any deal that takes Scotland and the UK out of the single market and customs union, causing untold damage to the Scottish economy. And since the current prime minister favours a harder, more isolationist and ideologically right-wing Brexit than even that fashioned by Mrs May, it is surely incumbent upon all UK opposition parties to fight tooth and nail to save the country from such a disastrous and isive path.Thatrsquos why they have no option but to vote down Mr Johnsonrsquos deal and force a general election, the circumstances of which will be vital in determining how it can be framed. After all, itrsquos not just Mr Johnsonrsquos tenure that must be keep short, but his list of options.The Lib Dems under Jo Swinson wonrsquot vote for any deal, not least because ldquogetting Brexit done would render their new "stop Brexit altogether" mandate redundant. And though itrsquos perhaps inevitable that some of the rebel Tories sitting on opposition benches might end up voting for the PMrsquos dealothers might decide to stick it to their former party and put the interests of the country first, especially since they are likely to lose their jobs anyway. The DUP, shafted by Mrs May, look set to be sold-out by her successor, too, and will vote against.Itrsquos Labour we have to worry about, particularly MPs representing Leave-voting areas that may be willing to fall into a Boris-shaped trap, voting through a deal that would allow the PM to take personal credit for ldquogetting Brexit done, handing him victory and a key element of their campaign. Would they be that stupid  I fear they would. It would be a cruel but perhaps not unexpected ironyLabour enabled a devastating hard Brexit to be foisted upon our poorest people.There is, as yet, no deal to put to parliament. But Boris looks increasingly frustrated and desperate. His options are running out. Time for opposition MPs of all colours to truly exploit this by working in a moredisciplined wayto close him down completely. We will simply never forgive themthey donrsquot.

title: greens-rule-electoral-pact-snp
story: On the closing day of the Green conference in Inverness, delegates overwhelmingly voted to stand alone at the  Holyrood election.The rejection came despite former co-convener Maggie Chapman, the partyrsquos leading list candidate in the north east, saying a pact with the SNP was ldquocertainly possible.She told The Herald ldquoIt is not something I would ever want us to rule out.However Ariane Burgess, the leading Green candidate for the Highlands and Islands, criticised this weekendrsquos SNP conference in Aberdeen having events sponsored by BP and Heathrow airport, and accused the other party of "selling out" to oil companies.Former SNP minister Stewart Stevenson also told a fringe event in Aberdeen that there would be ldquodecades of further oil extraction from the North Sea, albeit winding down.Ms Burgess said: ldquoOnly the Greens have what it takes to deliver the transformative change that is needed in the face of the climate emergency."Andyou want any proof, just look at SNP conference that is opening today. Brought to you by Heathrow Airport and BP, one of the biggest polluters in the world ever."Yet more proof that the SNPs rhetoric and eye-catching but distant targets are window-dressing, serving only to stave off criticism."For all their talk of change, they are the party of the status quo."Earlier, Green delegates voted to put climate issues at the heart of any negotiations over the Scottish Government Budget, with a motion calling for turning the "rhetoric of a climate emergency into a reality" by moving to a low carbon economy being passed at conference.Since , the minority SNP administration has relied on support from the Greens to pass its tax and spending plans at Holyrood, with the parking tax among the   concessions.Co-leader Patrick Harvie said the next budget ldquomust recognise the urgency of the climate emergency.

title: piers-morgan-cant-help-liking-nicola-sturgeon-exudes-leadership
story: In an interview, Mr Morgan had grilled the First Minister on Scottish independence and what he said was an inevitable border between Scotland and England creating the same problem that Ireland has now with Brexit.Ms Sturgeon told him a hard border was avoidable and she did not want a hard border.:Nicola Sturgeon in heated argument with Piers Morgan on Good Morning BritainShe also said: "We would continue to trade with the rest of the UK and the rest of the UK would trade with Scotland."She said the choice facing Scotland wasto either"decide ourown future or have it decided for us by people like Boris Johnson."Ms Sturgeon was speaking from Aberdeen where the SNP is holding its annual conference.After the interview, still speaking on air in the ITV studio, Mr Morgan compared the SNP leader to leaders at Westminster during the Brexit era.:Nicola Sturgeon accuses SNP rebels of helping UnionistsHe said: "I cant help liking Nicola Sturgeon.""She exudes leadership", he added.The controversial TV host said Theresa May didnt show that type of leadership.He added: "Nicola Sturgeon, whether you like her or not has a clear idea of what she wants for her country."

title: independent-scotland-join-eu-relatively-comfortably-says-law-professor
story: Edinburgh Law School professor Drew Scott said that there had been a change in attitudes in Brussels since the Scottish referendum in .And he dismissed previous suggestions that Spain could veto EU membership for an independent Scotland because of its stance on Catalonia.:Support for Scottish independence rises to %, according to new pollSpeaking at a fringe event on Europe at the SNP conference in Aberdeen, professor Scott said:ldquoThe mood in Brussels today is quite dferent from the mood in Brussels in  before the independence referendum." alt"HeraldScotland: Professor Scott political point, it just is a fact of le that there is now a much higher degree of recognition that Scotland is a mainstream European country where % voted to remain, and I suspect although itrsquos nations and would continue to contribute as it has done.ldquoWe donrsquot make enough in this country, and I mean Scotland now, of the contributions that wersquove actually added to the European assuming we had achieved independence by a constitutional due process.:Mark Smith: A declaration that can offer an alternative to SNPldquoThe Spanish shadow is always raised but I think Spainrsquos the UK, then Spainrsquos got no particular problem with that because itrsquos a quite dferent situation from that which exists within Spain.ldquoSo I donrsquot see the shadow of a Spanish veto at all lying over this.

title: greta-thunberg-come-glasgow-un-climate-summit
story: The -year-oldrsquos public relations team has said that Greta ldquocould be interested in speaking at COP next November and that they ldquowould be in touch closer to the time.Glasgow is hosting COP which will see up to  heads of government from around the world and up to , delegates meet to draw up a new climate change strategy.:Greta Thunberg should be invited to visit GlasgowCouncillor Paul Carey wrote to Leader of the Council Susan Aitken askingit would be possible to invite the Swedish activist to speak to local school children.Councillor Carey said: ldquoI will write to the leader of the council again to request this. I have now written to the First Minister, asking her to consider inviting Greta to the Scottish Parliament during COP.Last month Greta addressed world leaders on climate change at the UN Climate Action Summit but has faced criticism from sceptics online.Mr Carey went on: ldquoI am appalled at the amount of abuse this young lady is getting on social media.ldquoShe is part of the solution and the people who are giving her this abuse are part of the problem.Fake organisations claiming to act on Gretarsquos behalf have surfaced claiming that Greta would only be interested in coming to Glasgowthe council could confirm they would be interested in promoting an insectoid protein diet and investing in solar nautical travel.Her associates say that Greta doesnrsquot have a position on those demands.A Scottish Government has confirmed they would like to see Miss Thunberg take part in COP.A spokesman said: ldquoWe would be delighted to see Greta visit Scotland for the COP conference and we will respond to any approach from her or councillor Carey.:Greta Thunberg makes impassioned plea for climate action at UNldquoItrsquos right that the event should come to Scotland given our global leadership on climate action and wersquore sure Glasgow will deliver a highly successful conference.A council spokesman added: ldquoGreta Thunberg is welcome to come to Glasgow at any time.

title: dennis-skinner-heckles-black-rod-refuses-attend-queens-speech
story: The Beast of Bolsover is known for his quips as MPs follow Black Rod to the House of Lords.Skinner appeared to mutter ldquoIrsquom not going after Black Rod requested MPsrsquo attendance.:Queens Speech outlines governments agenda as crunch Brexit talks continueThis prompted laughter from both sides of the House of Commons.Black Rod has the door to the House of Commons slammed shut in her face.She is eventually allowed in and demands MPs meet The Queen in the House of Peers.Dennis Skinner makes his traditional quip as MPs follow her to the House of Lords#QueensSpeech #StateOpening pic bnVdgKFgMr Skinner is known for making quips during the State Opening of Parliament and it has become part of the pomp and circumstance of the event.Many social media users watched the speech just to listen out for the traditional comment from Skinner with one tweeting that he is a national treasure.I dont care what anyone says, the greatest national tradition we have is Dennis Skinner hecking during the Queens Speech.He remained behind in the Commons chamber.With the focus on criminal justice measures during the Queens Speech,the Queen said: ldquoNew sentencing laws will see that the most serious offenders spend longer in custody to reflect better the severity of their crimes.Im only interested in the #QueensSpeech to hear Dennis Skinner and his mighty heckles. pic uCLrpEACuA Sentencing Bill will change the automatic release point from halfway to two thirds for adult offenders serving sentences of four years or more for serious violence or sexual offences.Other measures include strengthening environmental protections, reforming adult social care and improving the NHS, and raising living standards through increasing the national living wage to pound. an hour.

title: snp-conference-calls-new-quango-promote-scots-language
story: Delegates voted to explore the idea of a Scots Language Board ndash or "Board fir the Scots Leid" ndash similar to the Bograverd na Gagraveidhlig, which promotesGaelic.They said Scots shouldbe more widely taught, learned and promoted as part of Scottish public le, and notedthe "years of linguistic prejudice" it has suffered.SNP MSP Emma Harper said: "We need to treat the Scots language equally. We need aBoard fir the Scots leid."Another delegate, Charlotte Armitage, said Scots deserves the "status and respect that we give other indigenouslanguages".She added: "The one and a half million people who speak Scots in Scotland, including me, should not have to feel afraid when blethering awa in their ainmither tongue."A motion passed by the conference said it "understands that Scots is not fully recognised as an official language of Scotland, and notes the impact that this has on the ability of Scots speakers to learn or promote their native tongue".It added: "Conference calls on the Scottish Government to support the promotion of Scots language as part of celebrating Scotlandrsquos linguistic ersity and to undoing the years of linguistic prejudice that the language has suffered."Conference encourages the idea of a statutory Scots Language Boardto be explored on a similar basis as Bograverd na Gagraveidhlig."The Scots language motionA Scots translation of the motion was also provided.It read: "The Collogue awns the importance o the Scots Leid in oor shared cultural identity, no least i the UN year o hamelt leids."The Collogue unnerstauns at Scots isna fully recogneized as an offeicial leid o Scotland, an taks tent o whit this means for the abeility o Scots speakers tae laern or forder their mither tung."Mairower, as Scots is at the hert o the identity o monie communities the lenth o Scotland, it shuid be mair widely laernt an fordert as airt an pairt o Scotlandrsquos public le."The Collogue caws on the Scottish Guivernment tae gie a heize tae the Scots Leid as pairt o a celebration o Scotlandrsquos rowth o leids, an tae undae the linguistic ill-wull at the tung haes hed tae dree."The Collogue encuirages a Board fir the Scots Leid tae be explored on a like basis tae Bograverd na Gagraveidhlig."

title: nicola-sturgeon-blames-snp-election-loss-turnout
story: The First Minister suggested the SNPrsquos loss of almost half-a-million votes and a third of its MPs at the  election had been influenced by voter numbers, not unpopularity.Ms Sturgeonrsquos second election as SNP leader saw the party fall from  MPs won in  to  after Ruth Davidson led a Scottish Tory surge based on defending the Union.The snap election was called just a few months after Ms Sturgeon announced plans for a second independence referendum, galvanising Unionist opposition.The SNPrsquos share of the vote fell from  to . per cent, while the Scottish Tory vote rose from . to .%, Labourrsquos rose from . to .%, and the LibDem fell from . to .%.:Piers Morgan "I cant help liking Nicola Sturgeon, she exudes leadership"In terms of absolute votes, the SNP fell from ,, to ,, a drop of ,.The Scottish Tories rose from , to ,, Scottish Labour rose from , to ,, and the Scottish LibDems fell from , to ,.While the SNP lost  MPs, the Tories went from one to , Labour from one to seven, and the LibDems from one to four.It was the SNPrsquos worst reverse since it lost nine of its  MPs in .Both turnoutand the size of the electoratewere indeed smaller in  than in .However, the total number of votes cast was , lower, much less than the , lost by the SNP.Nor do turnout and electorate size explain the rise in votes and MPs for other parties.Ms Sturgeon acknowledged at the time that Indyref had been a factor in the election results, telling MSPs that ldquohaving listened and reflected she would ldquoreset her plan.:Boris Johnson again dismisses out of hand Nicola Sturgeons attempt to hold second independence referendumHowever speaking to BBC Breakfast from the SNP conference in Aberdeen, Ms Sturgeon took a dferent line when was asked about the  drop-in votes, and why she was confident of more support in future.She replied: ldquoWell, Irsquoll come on to that point in a minute. But I should say, just so wersquore putting this in some context, that the SNP has won every single one of these elections. Wersquove comfortably won all of these elections.Pressed again on the drop in SNP between  and , she said: ldquoWell of course that will be affected by turnouts in elections, but anyway I wonrsquot labour that point.ldquoIrsquom simply making the point that the way you asked that question sounds aswersquove suffered some electoral failures, which we havenrsquot. Wersquove won all of these elections.ldquoBut what gives me confidence now is the polls. In a party sense, the SNP, in government for  years, we are streets ahead of our opponents in terms of polling evidence.ldquoAnd on the question of independence, we had a poll yesterday [Sunday] showing that independence support is up to %, a record in that particular poll.ldquoSo we see rising support for independence, we see rising support in Scotland for the demand to have a choice about our future.Although the SNP lost seven councillors in the  local election, the party has fared much better in recent polls and had its best-ever result in a European election in May.The SNP won half of Scotlandrsquos six MEPs as its vote share rose from  to .% and Labour collapsed from  to % and lost both its MEPs.The Tories, LibDems and Brexit Party each won one MEP.The SNP failed to win the Holyrood by-election in Shetland inAugust but did increase its share of the vote.

title: eu-set-hard-border-independence-russell-confirms
story: Michael Russell told a fringe event at the SNP conference in Aberdeen that the border would be ldquogoverned by our membership of the EU, not settled domestically.On Sunday, Nicola Sturgeon refused to rule out infrastructure and customs checksBrexit was combined with Scottish independence in Europe.She said she would be ldquohonest and frank about the issue with voters before Indyref.:Sturgeon refuses to rule out hard border with England after independenceHowever in TV interviews on Monday, she suggestedborder arrangements would be for Scotland and the rest of the UK to sort out, downplayingthe role of Brussels.She said she would ldquomake sure that Scotland continues to trade with the rest of the UK in the same way that the rest of the UK will have big interests in continuing to trade with Scotland.She added: ldquoIt would be my intention that [a hard border] does not happen.If Scotland were in the EU after independence and England was outand the trading regimes wee dferent, the EU would want to secure the border between the two to ensure that neither the single market or EU customs union was undermined.Mr Russell told activists: "There will be issues that will confront us as an independent country which we will have to recognise and respond to."The issue of the relationship between countries and borders between countries, of course, will be an issue."But it will be governed by our membership of the EU, that is the important issue, just as Irelands relationship with the UK will be governed."SNP MEP Alyn Smith added: "If the border looks like Northern Ireland,the border looks like Sweden to Norway,the border looks like France into Switzerland there are exemplars that already exist and the EU is looking at this stuff as well.":Nicola Sturgeon in row over unofficial email accountAsked on ITVrsquos Good Morning Britainan independent Scotland in the EU could avoid a hard border with a post-Brexit England, Ms Sturgeon said:ldquoWe donrsquot yet know how the UK is going to resolve its longer term future with the European Union.ldquoWhen we do that then we take those decisions in terms of how we make sure that Scotland continues to trade with the rest of the UK in the same way that the rest of the UK will have big interests in continuing to trade with Scotland.ldquoBut at the end of the day this is about whether itrsquos Scotland that decides our future, that we take into account all of the implications of being independent, all of the challenges, all of the opportunities, and we decide our own future.Later, on BBC Breakfast, Ms Sturgeon was askedshe accepted a hard border would have to be created between Scotland and England because of independence and Brexit.She said: ldquoNo, I donrsquot accept that, and it would be my intention that does not happen.ldquoAnd before Scotland takes that decision on independence we would set out how we would intend to ensure that trade flows between Scotland and the rest of the UK and vice versa would continue, because itrsquos important that they do.ldquoObviously the detail of that, and this is where Irsquom not going to try and pull the wool over peoplersquos eyes, the detail of how we achieve that depends on the final relationship between the UK and the EU. We donrsquot know what thatrsquos going to be yet.So I will, as the independence campaign did in , wersquoll put forward all of these facts and arguments so that people in Scotland can make an informed choice about our future, in contrast to the kind of choice that was made over Brexit.ldquoI want there to be a genuinely informed choice for Scotland.:Sturgeon blames  election reverse on turnoutScottish Labour leader Richard Leonard said: "Whether its a hard border or the hard cuts of the so-called Growth Commission, the SNP has shown it is determined to pursue a separate state evenit badly hurts the people of Scotland."A hard border between Scotland and England would cost jobs, hurt our public services and ide families. Our communities donrsquot need more barriers and disruption.Tory MSP Murdo Fraser said: ldquoThe SNPrsquos economic case for independence has never been weaker.ldquoNow we have Nicola Sturgeon admitting a hard border could be put upher plans to break Scotland away from the rest of the UK come to fruition.ldquoAll of this would make Scotland poorer, our businesses less competitive and put hardworking Scots right up against it.Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, added: ldquoNicola Sturgeon must come clean on the devastating impact of a hard border with England. The SNP must produce its own lsquoYellowhammerrsquo document that spells out the consequences of Scexit.ldquoWe know it would be catastrophic for our economy, as we trade nearly poundbillion with the rest of the UK.ldquoIt would put livelihoods at risk as over half-a-million jobs in Scotland are supported by the rest of the UK.ldquoAnd it would put freedom of movement at risk after more than  years.

title: ellon woman heads off on mercy mission
story: Ellon woman Sandra Campbell is preparing for a five-week trip to the West African nation of Senegal where she will be volunteering as a nurse.The -year-old is travelling to the Africa Mercy, the world’s largest charity-run hospital ship, which provides healthcare and training to developing countries.Sandra was inspired to volunteer by a visit to the previous ship, the Anastasis, and learning about the amazing work they did to bringing hope and healing to thousands of people who do not have access to affordable health care. “The surgical care given to patients is truly le transforming for these patients and their families and it is thrilling to be able to be part of it and to see the smiles on their faces when they leave the ship to go home to a better future,” she said.The floating hospital is staffed almost entirely by volunteers from over  dferent nations who work in a iety of roles to help change the lives of some of the world’s poorest people.Mercy Ships has touched more than . million lives since .“We are so grateful for the volunteers who travel to the Africa Mercy to volunteer their time and skills. Only % of the roles on the ship are medical and every role is filled by a volunteer,” said Hannah Mulvihill, Crew Support Co-ordinator for Mercy Ships.“From the cleaners to the nurses, the receptionists to the electricians we couldn’t offer this vital service without them.”As for Sandra, she is preparing for cabin le, stating: “I have volunteered with Mercy Ships since  and spend several weeks on the ship each year. I always look forward to my times onboard and meeting with shipmates I have worked with before and new ones from all over the world. “It is a great atmosphere to work in as each of us comes with the same desire to serve and make a dference,” she added.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Women aged - years of age who are registered with a General Practitioner at Fyvie Oldmeldrum Medical Group will receive an invitation to attend." title: first minister visits inverurie community campus
story: The Inverurie Health and Care Hub will accommodate an estimated , patients in its  consulting rooms within five years, doubling that of the previous GP practice.The First Minister also viewed construction progress at the £ million Inverurie Community Campus, which is part of new school construction projects worth £ million underway across the north of Scotland.She visited the campus site along with local MSP Gillian Martin.Speaking after touring the health and school facilities in Inverurie, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoThis new health facility in Inverurie is an excellent example of integrated health and social care, providing people with services located in a single setting, at the heart of the community.ldquoIt is exactly in line with our vision of improving primary care by allowing GPs to focus their skills where they add most value and allowing patients to be seen at the right time by the right person.ldquoThe new £ million Inverurie Community Campus will be a massive boost for the town giving young people state of the art world class facilities in which to learn.ldquoThese facilities are two of many new infrastructure projects planned as part of our signicant investment in the north east."Ms Martin said: ldquoI was pleased to visit Inverurie Community Campus today with the First Minister where we got an update of the construction progress.ldquoThe campus will bring world class facilities to young people and communities of the North-east. I welcome the news that the site will be operational in March next year and opened in spring of .ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to improving Scotlandrsquos school estate and ensuring we get education right for every child in Scotland.The Inverurie Community Campus is funded as part of the £. billion Scotlandrsquos Schools for the Future programme. data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Dogs"  These are the top  predicted dog names for  viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: mobile breast screening service at oldmeldrum
story: The North East Scotland Mobile Breast Screening Service will commence screening in Oldmeldrum on Tuesday, October #until early December.The mobile unit will be sited at Fyvie Oldmeldrum Medical Group, Academy Way, Oldmeldrum.Women aged - years of age who are registered with a General Practitioner at Fyvie Oldmeldrum Medical Group will receive an invitation to attend.The letters are sent out  weeks before their appointment date. Women aged  years and over are not sent an invitation, however, they are encouraged to make their own appointment by contacting the Screening Centre .Mrs Elspeth Hay, manager for the Breast Screening Service said: “The aim of the programme is to detect breast changes at an early stage when treatment has the best chance of being successful. "We hope that women invited for the first time will take advantage of their invitation for mammography and for women who have been screened previously, it is important to attend to ensure that there have been no changes over the past three years. "The risk of developing breast cancer increases as you get older, soany woman missed or failed to attend their previous invitation, it is still important to come along for screening this."data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Jobs"  These are the ‘happiest’ and ‘unhappiest’ jobs viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: thousands spent on targeted facebook adverts by scottish politicians
story: Facebook users are being targeted with thousands of adverts seeking to influence their opinion of local politics.Hundreds of inidual MPs, elected officials and local authorities have placed nearly half a million pounds’ worth of promotions on the site in less than a year, we can reveal.In the wake of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, the social media giant last year began publishing details of who places – and pays for – adverts promoting political or social issues. Spending on these ads, often targeted to specic groups, has totalled more than £. million since last October.And while much of the attention has focused on the big parties and pressure groups on either side of the Brexit ide, the data also reveals the thousands of adverts placed at a local level, often seeking to influence constituents on what can appear to be seemingly mundane neighbourhood issues.Under new rules Facebook introduced in October , anyone placing a political advert must declare who paid for it.Our investigation identied around  ads on the pages of local politicians and councils which were run without these disclaimers – including  placed on behalf of sitting MPs.There is no suggestion that any of the adverts had been deliberate attempts to deceive constituents. They were all found and removed by Facebook.Most adverts placed by or on behalf of Scottish MPs from October  to September , , were for amounts less than £.There were a few exceptions – £ spent by Gordon Conservatives, £ by Lib Dem leader and East Dunbartonshire MP Jo Swinson, £ by Angus Conservatives, £ by the Perth and Kinross Conservative Association, £ by Linlithgow MP Martyn Day, and £ by the Conservative Party.For MSPs, the majority also spent sums less than £ promoting material on Facebook.The exceptions were former Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson , Anas Sarwar , Johann Lamont , Liam Kerr , Alex Rowley , Alexander BurnettPeter Chapman , Beatrice Wishart , Richard Leonard , and West Lothian Courier Partners .Two Scottish local authorities spent money with Facebook – City of Edinburgh Counciland the SNP Group on North Ayrshire Council .data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..!
